Campus.Review: The campus has a nice scenery and outside there are farmer's markets, diverse restaurants, and the school's theater to take advantage of. Riverside Park is a great place to run and experience nature at its finest in New York City. Columbia has a nice balance of the city life and nature if you need it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's NYC – Really, you don't need a car. Student parking doesn't really exist in NYC. Public transit or just walking is the way to go!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Beautiful, but It's a Small Campus – columbia has a stunning campus. libraries are great. student center - is okay. there is always too little space on campus for student actitivies. and there is a sports center on campus, but the main one is 200 blocks away (ie subway trip away)
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Rain in Ny Sucks – buy boots, umbrella, rain coat. it will rain. it will be freezing. you will have to walk 10-15 minutes in such weather to get to class.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review:
Good but Not Great – The athletic center has a small track, basketball courts, weight rooms and a large gym for basketball, soccer, volleyball or any sport. However, the facility as a whole is a little too small and you will need to compete for space and workout machines.
The libraries are great and huge but their size is misleading. During exams, just study in your room and skip the 30 minute search for a seat in the library.
The campus is beautiful but Columbia cares too much about its grass. Consequently, you will not be able to play on the lawns often.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Students can choose to take their chances on the street, but risk being towed or they can pay an obscene amount of money for a parking garage.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The Subway Is the Best Way to Get Around – Public transportation is the best way to get around New York City. There is no necessary transportation to get around campus itself.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review:
As a student at Columbia there is little to none on campus transportation provided by the school That is because - it is simply not necessary. Everything on each campus is in walking distance. However, if you need to go visit a different campus you may take the shuttle bus. 

If you want to go anywhere in NYC - there is always the subway and bus system right next to campus. It is easy to use and is the most common form of transportation utilized by students.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Walk / Subway – Most people do not own a car.  People mostly walk or take a subway to campus.  These are fast and efficient ways to get to campus and make car ownership unnecessary and parking struggle nonexistent.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Terrible parking situation.  No Columbia lots, but there are garages which can run $50-75 dollars per day. HORRIBLE.  Columbia offers no parking of its own.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Dirty, Dangerous, Ugly – Columbia has a very tiny campus that boarders on a dangerous neighborhood.  Most buildings are covered in soot, and just appear very dirty. The campus has hedges around everything which literally shout "keep off."  The interior of buildings vary O.k. to disgusting.  In all, the school is i poor shape.  You would think an Ivy League University with this kind of endowment would do much better.  This is why Columbia is the ugliest, dirtiest and most dangerous of all the Ivy League schools.  Shameful.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It's usually kind of crappy weather, but with a bit of luck global warming will help us out and it will slowly get warmer. This year we barely had a winter.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computers in the schools are constantly being updated. The only problem is what has already been said: that it is often hard to find a work station during midterm/final week. The key, however, is that people don't utilize all of the computer labs in the school, so all you have to do is find a few that nobody uses. Printing is restricted to 100 sheets but you almost never end up using that much and network reliability on the campus is good most of the time.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The Accessibility of Cafeterias and Libraries – The cafeterias are all within a 5 minute walking distance from on-campus housing so it is really convenient. There is an abundance of beautiful and quiet libraries to study in, but during finals it may be a hassle finding a spot. However, if one goes early one can enjoy the tranquility of studying in one of our majestic libraries.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: What A Joke – If you even thought about needing a car, you should be checked by a doctor. This is NYC!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Subway System  and Cabs Rock – What's more convenient than the NYC subway system or hailing a cab? I wouldn't even laugh at someone who brings a car here; I would personally check them in to a mental hospital. No parking ever. You have everything you need just a subway swipe away.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's New York – What else is there to say? Places to eat, places to drink, places to do everything you could imagine and then some. Around Morningside Heights, there's fancy food (Community, Il Cibreo), good old standards (Koronet's, Absolut Bagels), parks (Central Park, Morningside Park, and Riverside Park) and amazing neighborhoods like Harlem and the Upper West Side. New York is a fabulous place to go to college--except whatever you do, draw up a budget before you go, because having a good time is EXPENSIVE.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: All buildings are within walking distance.  The furthest dorm is about half a mile away from campus, but very few people elect to live there.  You will be able to get to your classes in 10 minutes or less.  If there is a sporting event at the off-campus athletic complex (Baker), there are free coach buses, and the subway is a great option as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Dodge has excellent resources for athletes, while it is mediocre for non-athletes.  The cardio machines are often full.  I have not been to the general use weight room, but the dance room is beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Seriously... It's NYC – No one in their sane minds buys or uses a car here. NYC has over 20 train lines, ever-expanding into letters of the alphabet we barely use. In addition to this, there are extensive bus routes and taxis at every corner. Well to answer the question, I imagine parking would be a hassle if one hypothetically drove a car here. If.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great Stuff – Everything gets crowded, but for good reason. Everything is good.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: We're in the City Duh – We're in freaking NYC plus we're an Ivy League. Enough said.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You'd Actually Pick Dartmouth Over This? Other schools just seem so boring now that I've been here for 6 months, and this coming from someone who was nearly content to go to a tiny New England liberal arts school. That said, just come confident and ready to do things you might not expect to do, and you'll have an amazing time!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Need to Park on Streets – Obviously you have to park on New York streets so it's usually busy and crowded, but at least getting dropped off during orientation you can drive on College Walk
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Fine If You're Not in a Hurry – Computer labs in most dorms and buildings; very accessible. Printers often broken down, computers load incredibly slowly, so if you're sitting down to work it's fine but if you're in a rush then you need to use printatcu.com or such
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There is no doubt that the four years I spend here will be well worth it, in terms of the academic challenges, my personal and social growth, my NYC experiences, and the amazing people I meet here. As an engineer, my major requirements and classes are generally demanding, and the same is true of my peers in the college. However, if you enjoy a challenge and are passionate about what you study, the hard work is worth it. Professors are top-notch. As a freshman undergrad, I have the opportunity to take physics under the instruction of a CERN particle physicist, work in a research lab with nationally recognized professors, and attend events featuring world leaders. The Columbia experience is one that I will truly remember for the years to come.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Columbia University is a rigorous institution with numerous opportunities for intellectual, social, personal and professional growth. The combination of an Ivy League education and its location in the greatest metropolis on the east coast make for a truly fantastic college experience. Everything from your interaction with Columbia peers to events hosting world-renowned leaders will make your four years here very special.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: All Four Seasons – Personally, I love seasons, so the Northern climate with relatively hot summers and cold winters is fine for me.  Campus is easy to navigate in general, and a little rain or snow doesn't change that. On the main campus, most of the walkways are brick, so if the weather isn't good, leave the heels at home, but otherwise, it's fine.  The only real difficulty would be for anyone with a physical disability, because the wheelchair ramps and pathways aren't the best for navigation.  I think Columbia should do a better job making campus more accessible to those with physical limitations, but it honestly isn't the worst, as there are ramps and elevators and campus is salted after snow in a very timely fashion.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: "The But" – Butler Library is the quintessential Columbia icon.  Also crowded during stressful academic periods, "The But" is open 24 hours and has a cafe for your caffeine needs.  Also, Butler is host to Orgo Night which is always particularly fun.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Mostly Crowded, Some Printers Are Less Reliable Than Others – A ton of people use the computers and printers on campus and at rush hour times there is a huge line for printers wherever you are.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Cars Are Completely Unnecessary – The subway is right at 116th and broadway. Although Columbia doesn't subsidize the cost, it doesn't really matter as most kids don't use it that often. Buses connect you to other parts of the city.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Lots to Do – The great thing about studying and living in New York is your access to everything. There are lots of cultural attractions, great restaurants, and places to shop. If one neighborhood doesn't interest you, another definitely will.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Not Ideal, but Does the Job – Wireless access is pretty good on campus. My main complaint would be the number of computers in dorms, but I guess there are enough computer labs on campus overall.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's Okay – Classes never get cancelled even if all other schools around get days off. Weather is just surprising here with either really freezing winters or just warm and mild winters. You never know what to expect.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Don't Drive – There really is no need to even have a license here or a car here. New York's MTA system will take you anywhere you need to go. Everything on campus is within walking distance if you don't care to travel around and see New York.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: There is a lot to do like go to Madison Square Garden
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Rain and Snow. What is unfortunate is that we will never get a snow day because Columbia is So efficient at clearing all of the walkways. Rain is extremely irritating to walk through.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Public transportations is very convenient and cheap. Subway and buses are very practical and, if ever in need, taxis are everywhere.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New York City – The possibilities in NYC are endless. Whether interested in museum visits, Broadway shows, concerts or shopping, there is much to do. Even though NYC can seem overwhelming, there are actually many students and it is an easy city to navigate. The area around Columbia University is very student-friendly. A plus is that with your university ID, there are tons of attractions you can get in free of charge.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The atmosphere sucks, but you can easily hop on the subway to head downtown. A lot of people feel boxed in on campus and don't usually take the effort to head downtown. I agree, and would have liked it if columbia felt more homey.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It Works – There are computer labs in every main academic building and in several of the living buildings. The labs are quite busy so it takes a while to find an available computer but it isn't uncontrollable. Each student is given a quota of 100 pages of black and white printing a week and most printing can be done on both sides of a a page. As for internet access, wifi is in several buildings across campus but is not available in most dorm buildings. An ethernet cord is needed for access to internet in dorm rooms.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The Subway Is Awesome – Since everything is so close, walking is the best option.  The Subway helps to transport students all around New York City.  Cabs are also a last minute option.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: You Can Go Anywhere! MTA local service (subway, bus, rail) is reliable and well-planned, and goes all through the city.  Greyhound and Amtrak, and all the major airline carriers, can get you anywhere in the country in the world.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: there isn't a designated parking lot for students or faculty, therefore being located in NYC, across from a major hospital makes finding parking a nightmare. Aside from this problem there are also many areas where parking is strictly with parking meters.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Can't Beat New York – Being in New York City is awesome--never a lack of things to do. That can also be a problem when you really want to go out and do something, but also really need to get homework done. It is a tricky balance, but definitely worth it. NYC has something for everyone, whether it's Broadway, museums, parks, clubs-- you name it. And it's pretty easy to find student discounts for most stuff.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The Ivy League experience! Core curriculum!  New York connections! Everything!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Mac, Windows, Linux available - mostly Windows.  Printers all over campus, 100 free pages a week.  Network is usually good.  Wi-Fi in most of the building, access growing.  Most students have a laptop, usually a Mac.  You could have either and do fine here.  Few students have a printer.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather in NYC is great. It's typically tolerable weather. It's always sunny. And, a few months out of the year it'll rain or snow. The streets are plowed when it snows. The weather doesn't affect public transportation. It's always running.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Transport Is Everywhere – Buses, subways, taxis.  You can always get around the city at any hour.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: NYC has everything you need and is safe.  Lots of free attractions, parks, museums.  You can get discount tickets to broadway shows and sporting events.  Check with the student center for details.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Lerner Hall – Lerner Hall is a good place to meet fellow students but there isn't a lot of space to sit for group projects and have study groups.  The food is also really expensive in the cafe.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: If You Have to Read This, You Should Visit the School – Columbia is in the middle of NYC. No one and I mean NO ONE drives.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Just the name brand education of Columbia university opens up so many doors, even after just one year. The city just makes it unrivaled for the ivys, NYC is just amazing, especially when you aren't from here and its your first time in a big city with a whole bunch of other college kids.
I hear CO-OP was one of the funnest experiences for many people who did it, and I really wish that I did it as a freshman. 
The opportunities that appear after attending Columbia are just endless, and if you can afford it, it will likely be worth it in the long run.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Cold and Snowy – I am from southern california, so I dont deal well with the snow
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
And Never the Twain Shall Meet (Part 1) – Can't decide between big city or tight-knit campus? I couldn't either until I visited Columbia for the first time for Days on Campus. I touched down in LaGuardia and was immediately thrown head first into the NYC hustle and bustle - the sweet sounds of honking taxis complete with drivers flipping you off for walking in front of them and hot dog sellers on every street corner. In terms of city life- what city can really claim to rival "The Big Apple"?

Needless to say, Broadway is amazing, but there's also Soho, Hell's Kitchen, Chinatown, and Lincoln Center. (Lincoln Center is awesome if you have an unexpected night free- show up an hour before the show and get a student rush ticket for $15!)

Plus, with a Columbia ID you get free admission into almost every museum in NYC, and if you want to party- NYU is just a subway ride away.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The school offers parking optins, but your best bet is to take the subway.  It is most conveinenant and you will never have to drive in NY.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Subway Is Best Option – New York's MTA offers cheap public transportation and Columbia has their own subway stop for the local 1 Train located near the center of campus (116th/Broadway). For a fare of $2.25, a student can travel anywhere in Manhattan on the subway. MTA buses run frequently and usually on-time as well, for the same fare. Taxis are relatively expensive but very convenient and easy to catch.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Dodge Athletic Complex – Columbia's main gymnasium is quite nice, offering many classes, personal trainers, and well-functioning, available equipment for all work-out needs.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Local Atmoshpere – The local atmosphere of New York City is great.  There is always something going on and something to do no matter what kind of activity one is looking for.  The area Columbia is located is safe, as a girl living off campus I have never felt endangered in any way.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Plenty of Change – The weather in NY is rough in the winter, but it's easy to dress accordingly.  Th echange in seasons provides a new and different experience (and wardrobe) every few months.  I like that.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There is no parking at Columbia.  I would rate it a much lower grade, but really there is no need for a car.  None at all.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very Politically Active – Has a reputation for politically active students, particularly on the left.  Good for students interested engaging in activism.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Computers were pretty widely available across campus, while printers were mostly located in the libraries.  Having a personal computer is required, and it's probably best to have a laptop.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: You can get anywhere really easily-- subways, buses, taxis. Gotta take traffic into account though.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather here is very nice in the fall and Spring, and bitter cold in the winter. It rains a lot, and when it does, it rains all day. The wind chill is awful. Buy a GOOD coat.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: While much of the campus was wifi, most Columbia housing does not. Students are stuck to ethernet chords or must install their own router, but even this doesn't work too well because of overlapping frequencies. Printers are sometimes broken down, but are usually dependable.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: General Campus – The campus architecture is amazing. The classical architecture of the school fits in well with the classical core curriculum that all Columbia College students take. The campus is lovely and is a nice oasis away from the busy city life around it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The brand name itself opens doors wherever I go. However, Columbia is one of few schools in the city that doesn't let students tale internships for credit, which disqualifies all of its students from many prestigious and worthwhile internships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The career services and alumni network are unmatched
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: We have OCR and we're in New York City so that puts us ahead of a lot of schools. You'll probably be fine.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The alumni network is fairly active, and CCE does a great job of consistently reaching out to students and notifying them of internship/job opportunities.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: the took far more time to send their answer about my acceptance than expected which put me on a rush
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There are so many career and internship prospects as a result of going to Columbia. I know the university does its very best to give its students access to many internships in a huge range of fields.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I think that a Columbia degree is extremely valuable in that the knowledge you acquire here stays with you, even if you're struggling to find a job immediately after you graduate. Likewise, there is an extensive alumni network and many internship opportunities.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: From what I have heard, Columbia's alumni network is a huge asset.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: My senior friends have all found amazing jobs and there are so many opportunities the school set up for us in turns of alumni events and a career portal with job/internship listings.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I will have a job when I graduate that is amazing.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: If you want to do finance or consulting it is great.  Otherwise it is hit-or-miss.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I hope to do research after graduation, and that seems to be a reality.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The alumni network is great! I have been able to network with alumni at Columbia University and have made connections both on the east coast as well as on the west coast. They have helped me with job prospects. I plan to earn my license as a clinical social worker and from there moving to a position in higher education.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The opportunities are great if you're interested in staying in the city after you graduate but beyond that there isn't anything special.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Most of the companies that showed up for events were interested in market themselves, not recruit. If you are an international student, it is very, very hard to get an internship. Me and a friend applied for some 80 internship positions last Spring We had no answers at all.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Career center is excellent and very helpful
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: There are tons of opportunities to land an internship and get a job; you just have to get out of your room and apply.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I think Columbia has a great relationship with their alumni and this relationship helps undergrads find internships/jobs with those alumni who are working. There are many career fairs throughout the year and they have many seminars about resume writing and interviews
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Columbia University's career center manages a great job/internship database that keep students updated on ongoing and future career opportunities. It also hosts regular walk-in or by appointment hours to help students navigate their career search preparation from showing them how to use the database website, edit resume and cover letter, and giving so many more advice. The center also hosts undergraduate career fair every semester.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Colunbia's reputation speaks volumes. We are constantly given the opportunity to interact with alumni in order to form relationships that will support us during our time at Columbia and ultimately lead to successful futures after.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Well, as a freshman, I'm really hoping that the job prospects are good... I definitely think that this degree will be valuable come graduation. The internship network is solid, and career fairs on campus are pretty common with a couple of big names in terms of finance and business.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It remains to be seen, as success is determined by the person. However the education is still top-notch.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The business, theatre, music, art, computer science, and health departments are good. Otherwise, I don't know why you'd want to attend Columbus state.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They don't give enough aid and you have to fight them to increase work study stipends.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Columbia does not provide much support to grad students. I am attempting to secure funding from other sources.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Everything so far has been straight forward and everyone has been helpful.  The entire faculty in the journalism school is involved in student life and always willing to assist.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It's very hard to get financial aid... I applied for many of the school scholarships and what I received was barely any help.  Looking to outside scholarships anywhere I can find!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: At least in my experience, Columbia financial aid grants make it affordable, because realistically not very many people can pay the full cost of attendance.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Its great at first when you are under the impression that everything is covered. However, now I realize that it isn't the greatest as I starve over spring break.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There aren't a lot of options for scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Dealing with all the specific paperwork they want is a bit of a hassle but I think it is the same no matter where you go to school.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Be sure to apply for your FAFSA. You should be able to qualify for a reasonable amount of aid through that. Any other scholarships you can apply for are up to you. The more work you put into applying the better chances of getting at least one other and every little bit helps. Don't discriminate when it comes to free money! Try to apply for at least a handful of scholarships but know you will more than likely have to take out student loans to cover the rest of your tuition/living expenses.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Columbia is definitely one of the most respected schools in the nation.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Great financial aid, the department is very effective at giving money where it is needed efficiently.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I could have definitely used more, but it was reasonable.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Took away my grant halfway through Freshman year.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Financial aid is entirely based on your family's income. If you make under a certain amount, you WILL get what you NEED, but those of us in the middle get left out.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial Aid is extremely difficult to get for a family with average income and assets.  The application does not ask what hardships a family has taken or how secure your current income is. A home should not be taken as wealth, this is the place you live in.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The University has a strong reputation and is well respected in the industry.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: They provide a lot of financial aid, but it's still really expensive.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Everyone knows the name, and people value that recognition.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: It is an Ivy. So…. both the alumni networking and the career counseling are great, obviously. Columbia has the added advantage of being in the city, so students can partake in serious internships in the City during semester, adding to your resume without breaking the bank.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There was no scholarship or aid opportunity other than FAFSA for the program I am in.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I wish I got money.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Without my financial aid package I could not have attended.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Columbia has some very difficult policies regarding financial aid. For example, they meet 100% of projected need. However, if you receive outside scholarships, that money cannot be used to pay the remaining balance on your tuition, rather Columbia will just revoke some of it's aid and you are left with the same amount on the bill.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I need more aid than they are willing to give, though that is not to say they have given me nothing. I do receive aid and it is 100% of my "projected" need, but what they deem we can offer and what my family actually can are two very different things.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I received financial aid but my family still struggles to pay the amount that is expected of us.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Columbia has fairly generous policies on scholarships, stipends, and fellowships, and you can usually find whatever financial support you need. The only negative: administrative crosstalk between departments is exceedingly weak, and the myriad offices (Global Programs, Financial Aid, Advising, etc.) are prone to miscommunication.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: The financial aid office is a scary place.  The process as a whole is ok, the people are nice,  but trying to understand the statement they send is a little mystifying.  I've had to ask several times what certain items are and how they have calculated them.  They are slow to respond, but eventually get around to it.  You just need to stay on top of it all.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: It's a continuing process, even after months of paperwork.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: At least in the law school, and this isn't fairly uncommon, scholarships are hard to come by. You either get them when you are admitted or you don't get them at all. There are also very few of them to begin with.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review:
If you're in extreme need, Columbia will cover almost all of your financial needs. But if you're like me, you're a kid from a middle class family whose parents' assets aren't all liquid but will nonetheless be taken into consideration by Financial Aid and may count against you. Surprisingly, however, Columbia offered me a FinAid package that covers about half of the total cost of attendance.

Although I still have to take out student loans and pursue some outside scholarships, I am generally happy with my FinAid situation and just having the opportunity to attend this school in the first place.

One last piece of advice would be to stay on top of your Financial Aid application and in good communication with your Financial Aid Officer. You will likely have to email back and forth and even send additional information before your package is finalized and ready for you to see, so be prepared and check your email often.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid office is wonderful.  They do everything they can to help you get the aid that you need to enroll in school
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: I didn't get offered any financial aid.  There are opportunities, but you need to search them out.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I filled out the necessary forms and online applications yet they wanted additional documents on various occasions and by the time my financial aid was fully processed it was late. I'm sure that I didn't get as much aid as I would've if they hadn't held up the process.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Since I am an international student, Columbia was not generous with scholarships for me although many of my american friends have gotten some scholarship. But those are funded by different people . I think columbia is stingy with scholarships.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Just like every other Ivy League school, Columbia doesn't offer merit bases scholarships. They do however have a large enough endowment to pay full tuition for families making under $60k a year and to %100 cover the demonstrated financial need of families making more than that.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Columbia has "need blind" financial aid.  Essentially, if you need financial aid once you have been admitted, they will give it to you, and also help you find loans, etc to cover what the school cannot provide for you.  You do need to get your paperwork in time, but even if all can't make the deadline with all your papers, your financial aid adviser will work with you to speed up the process, even give you forms to send to them directly instead of through Collegeboard.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It is written on the Columbia University website that majority of the students accepted receive a full scholarship or a very important amount to finance their education. It is false, when I got accepted, I only received $3,500 per semester. When you try to contact the financial aid office, you can easily schedule an appointment  with a financial advisor but they won't help you because Columbia does not have a lot of money as it claims to have on its website. Only few accepted students receive full scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Unless You're Completely Broke, Don't Bother – The title says it all. Unless you AND your family are nearly destitute don't bother applying for financial aid. You're better off looking at private funding and scholarships. Though I've heard you can leverage your offers with other schools to get a better deal when entering.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Not Equally Distributed – Financial Aid depends upon the college you attend at Columbia.  It is definitely NOT distributed equally amongst the schools.  A General Studies student pays far more to attend than a Columbia College student. This is because CC has a rule if you parents make under a certain amount, you get a free ride.  Not so at GS.  Financial services are also very slow to respond with scholarship, grant, and aid information.  I had until Spring of 2012 before my Fall of 2011 awards were posted.  Meanwhile, my record showed a hold on my account, preventing me from registering.  This happened to hundreds of students.  It was pure hell!
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Columbia has a pretty big endowment and is very generous for financial aid; only a few schools give more in terms of monetary aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Actually, the head of the financial aid department had a two hour phone session with me to figure out exactly the loan amount I needed.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: In my experience, Columbia gives out amazing financial aid. This is largely due to the school's policy to remove student loans from aid packages, making Columbia's aid markedly different from NYU (and many other larger institutions). My aid package was fair and lined up with my FAFSA EFC. The distinction between "Work-Study" and "Casual Employment" is a little fuzzy, and it is harder to get an on-campus job if you have the latter as part of your package.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid department is truly a nightmare.  Scholarship monies that were supposed to be credited to accounts due to adjustments in course credits never materialized.  Resultantly, holds were placed on student accounts, disallowing students to register for classes.  The issue took over one year to resolve.  Moreover, students were forced to pay late registration fees o $150 because of Columbia's error.  Students at The School of General Studies DO NOT have the same access to financial aid as those of Columbia College, even though their need is greater.  It's time to merge the two schools two stop this systemic financial discrimination directed a segment of the student population.  Shameful indeed.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: ... but hard to get if you're not truly needy.  If you are, it's a free ride (or close to it) for you.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Limited Amount – There's a quota to how much scholarship money you can use for your student contribution. Also, the entire financial aid process was a bit tedious.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
It is strictly need based, so there are no athletic scholarships at all. This keeps the prestige up and the students competitive. 
It is a hassle to go through, and is a very administrative/unfriendly process, but they do give decent amounts in the end.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Adequate university grants are extremely difficult for students to receive if they come from a middle-class family or have any kind of special circumstances. Financial aid advisors are unavailable and impossible to contact long-distance (a serious problem for parents and students who are away from campus - for example, during summer). Students are generally very unsatisfied with the financial aid office.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I received a good amount of financial aid once I filled out the necessary paperwork. The financial aid advisors are easy to get in contact with and the office usually has walk in hours all throughout the year. And the waiting period is not long at all.
Value.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Only speaking for the medical campus. There isn't a lot of diversity.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: For New York, it is not the best.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The quality of food in Morningside Heights in general is not great.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The food is okay for the price.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Since Columbia is situated in a very diverse and vibrant community, there are tons of cuisines to pick from. If you head a few blocks down, you there are entire strips of restaurants ranging from Thai to Ramen to Indian to Ethiopian. Take your pick!
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The food on campus is generally overpriced so I would recommend heading out to the multiple shops around campus that are unaffiliated with the school.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Only thing I'm missing is a Brazilian option.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I've had blood spurting out of chicken in one of my sandwiches before.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You can't really go wrong with finding good food in the middle of New York City... it's the best!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Every corner of campus has food available.  Most are affordable and fresh!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: You're in New York City. That pretty much means that you have every option available to you, if you have the time and/or patience.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Overall, I like the food. I would prefer a wider variety of hours, but the food itself is way above average in terms of dining hall food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's pretty good all around. NYC is expensive though, it'd be nice if things were cheaper. And I wish there were more things open late at night.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Never know what I'll get, it's all very hit or miss. The most frustrating thing is that it is not available at convenient hours.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: If your willing to get off campus a little ways, there are tons of eateries to explore! New York is such a diverse city so there is a little bit of every type of cuisine around. And most students know all the places to get the best deals if you ask around.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a decent amount of food on/around campus and they try to offer healthy selections but the best option is to try and bring your own food if you have time to meal prep. Otherwise you're sure to put on that freshman fifteen.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's food for the masses, but cool atmosphere in John Jay.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's generally nutritious (except JJ's place) and accomodating of dietary preferences, and while (like any cafeteria food) it gets old fast, sometimes the dining halls will surprise you (Ferris fish tacos, surf and turf). Honestly, while I've rarely had a really good meal, I've had very few meals that tasted bad- mostly ranges from bland but edible to pretty good. Ferris pasta station is always an option. The main downside to campus food is that the meal plan is quite overpriced, especially in comparison to the multitude great, practical dining options in Morningside Heights. Still, having eaten meals at other colleges and hosted friends from other colleges, I can say that Columbia's dining options are much better than the vast majority of college campus food, including most other pricy private universities.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Best food and options in the ivies.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: It's NYC, there's great food everywhere, and when you don't want to walk, there's always delivery
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's Manhattan - there are tons of options, and since Morningside Heights is a college area, nothing is too expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Something is always open, even for delivery, which is incredibly convenient.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Decent options in my opinion. John Jay, Ferris, and JJ's Place are the three main options. JJ's is the late night spot but doesn't always have the healthiest options.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Anything you could possibly want
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It ok for campus dining, not like home.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: In NYC the dining options are endless, but it's very expensive.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The food is good, wish there were more protein options
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: It's New York. Expensive, but anything you want, any time of the day or night. Awesome!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I have been to many different kinds of restaurants since I've been here. The 24 hour supermarket on broadway and 116th is very convenient.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: I would have liked and probably taken part in a dining plan for summer students.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There's a lot of great places to eat in Morningside Heights.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You can find any food type you desire in New York City, typically not far from wherever you are. Around campus there are food types ranging from just a slice of pizza to Ethiopian Cuisine. If someone is unable to find something good to eat, they just haven't looked.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: You can go to the diner or pick up pizza
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Again, its what you make of it - NYC has everything, if you are willing to travel a little bit
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: A decent amount of selection.  It is Manhattan so nothing is cheap.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I spend too much money on food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Living in New York means there's no end to restaurant options. There's a great deal of ethnic diversity in restaurants, including a Cuban, Korean, Halal and Mediterranean restaurant all on the same block.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I am not on a meal plan, but I have eaten in the dining halls before. As a freshman you are required to purchase an unlimited meal plan (19 meals a week) which is a huge waste and quite expensive. There are 3 dining halls but there can be little variety between them. Only one offers a kosher option, but it's much more extensive than other universities.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food options are great but after a while, you might get tired of them.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I mostly use the cafeteria. The food is not restaurant quality, but it is very easy to eat healthy, and there are plenty of options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There's shoddy diners for those who are so inclined, and there are upscale places for those who care. Plenty of variety.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Honestly it depends on where you eat and the day you go. There are three dining halls so there can be variety, but most of the time the food is more or less the same quality wherever you go. If you go somewhere where the food is good on that particular day, you're fine -- but otherwise, when the food is terrible, it's *really* terrible. Odds are you can find something you like but don't bank on every meal being the best.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is variety, but there is a finite number of choices available for the neighborhood.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: New York is arguably the culinary capital of North America. Whatever the preferences of your palate (or the size of your wallet), you'll find something to satisfy any craving at any hour.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: New York has endless choices for food at whatever price range you are looking for. Prices near Columbia are affordable and set for students. If you are willing to walk 10-15 and venture around the area, you can find exceptional food in any cuisine for any price.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's New York. You can get anything - fine dining, inexpensive, make your own.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Living in New York City in general is not cheap. However, around the campus of Columbia, there are many cheap places to eat. Only a couple blocks down from the campus are a couple of Starbucks, for the caffeine boost, and a Chipotle. There are also a couple other restaurants nearby. However, if you're looking for good eats, going a little more downtown is the best. One of my favorite places is called Cafe 28. It is down along 28th street and Broadway, a little ways down from where the campus is, but there is a large variety of dishes with the addition of a cafe. The food there is reasonably priced and prepared daily.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Again, this applies to the Health Science Center (168th St).  Washington Heights has a little variety, but to get to New York's more famous foods, you have to ride the 1 or A trains South for ~30 min.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are so many options to eat an NYC! One of the major must-dos when at Columbia is Coronets, where pizza slices are bigger than your head. There is also an amazing hungarian pastry shop on amsterdam where students flock to study at, along with many other cafes. Although the quality isn't amazing, there is the famous Tom's Restaurant, also known as "Tom's Diner" from Seinfeld.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I enjoy the food. There are many options to choose from; they offer Vegan, Vegetarian, and meaty dishes. Breakfast and lunch is best at Ferris; Brunch on the weekends and dinner during the week is best at John Jay Dining Hall; Late night food (til 1am) is offered at JJ's in the basement of the John Jay dorm. JJ's is a nice spot to grab breakfast 12am in the morning, sit and chat with friends, and watch television (they have several TV sets down there).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Love the quality of the food. It is way better than at my old college.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There is a good variety of food and because you have three different cafeterias to choose from (Hewitt, John Jay, and Ferris) along with several cafés and a late-night eatery (JJ's), so when you get bored with one cafeteria, you can always move on.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is sufficient variety in locations but food is average and prices are on the high side.  The road-side food trucks are amazing though!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The restaurants and cafes on campus are decent quality and fairly priced for NYC. In the Columbia neighborhood there are tons more restaurants and cafes to eat at, with a wide variety of ethnic and special-needs places as well.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: This is New York - you can get anything you want any time of day
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The places around campus are quite good, especially the cafes and dining halls. Most have gluten-free, vegan/ vegetarian options. The food is usually fresh and hygienically prepared and the halls are clean and well-maintained.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Columbia has many options around it. Just walk downtown to 90th streets and near by for great many varieties of thai, chinese, turkish, mexican and Japanese food. Pocket friendly options are many and you need to know the right places to go to.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: You literally have amazing food from every inch of the world at your fingertips. You just gotta save up some money. Many places around morningside offer a student discount.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's New York City so restaurants are amazing and there are plenty of them. But if you stick around the Columbia campus area, you'll get pretty tired of the food. Though there are a lot of restaurants, there's an abundance of burgers and sandwich places. There are way too many delis and it just gets old. However, during your first semester, you aren't likely to get tired of the food (given you're eating off campus sometimes and not only using the meal plan) since there are quite a lot of restaurants right off campus and even the street food changes on different days of the week.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is excellent because you're in New York City. While there are of course more expensive options, there are also affordable options for everyone that still provide great food (even if you might have to add Subway fare into your calculations). If you need something quick and tasty, there are halal carts right outside campus. New York's food scene leaves much to be explored.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New York City has an endless number of restaurants and food options from pretty much any kind of cuisine you could possibly want to eat.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Get Ready to Buy a Mealpass If You Want Food. Most students say that they know people who have bought meal plans and wish they have not. Students tend to purchase food off campus rather than on campus because places on campus that accept card/cash are rather expensive.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The best way to eat in NYC is by exploring the city - why would you eat in a dining hall when you have access to great restaurants everywhere.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's New York! I will say the same thing as everyone else: it's New York, a city known for food.  From the 5 star restaurant to the mom and pop to the taco truck.  Around campus is mostly sit down restaurants, moving into Harlem, there is more barbeque, fast food, and African restaurants.  South is the Upper West Side with some really fancy stuff.  Trendier and sometimes cheaper restaurants can also be found downtown or in the village.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
The More Subdued, the Better – Some places, especially in Union Square, the Lower East Side and Brooklyn, are best when not many people appear to frequent the place. The more subdued a shop appears to be, the better the atmosphere for studying and enjoying a meal with friends.

Nearest to campus, there is Smoke, El Porton and Max Cafe/Max Soha. Each of these places offer a chill atmosphere and awesome food.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I Expected More – With high tuition costs, I expected more out of Columbia dining. The food eventually becomes repetitive, so I resorted to cooking. Honestly, it's only a little better than cafeteria food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Going Beyond Morningside – There are some great restaurants in the Morningside Heights neighborhood, like Community Food and Juice and Le Monde, that are a bit pricy, but worth the expense.  There are also basic chain restaurants like Chipotle, Five Guys, etc.  However, the trick to finding great dining options is to hop on the 1 train and explore the city! There is nothing like living in New York City, and Columbia students who take advantage of events like Restaurant Week and other opportunities don't regret it!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
Great Variety and Taste – When you first eat at the dining halls, you will be overwhelmed by the sheer variety of foods available, and that feeling won't die for another month. As with all other things, campus food gets repetitive; luckily, however, there are quite a few locations that accept Flex/Dining Dollars on-campus (and Flex dollars off-campus) that have great food.  There are also some _amazing_ places on campus that only accept cash (and they are the places you will not regret spending on).

A lot of people choose not to go with a meal plan after freshman year, and a lot of people do. See what works better for you - meals from your dining plan, or a lot of flex/dining dollars. You can get meals at the dining halls with Flex/Dining Dollars, too.

Dining halls that accept the meal plan: Ferris Booth, John Jay Hall, JJ's Place (this place is amazing for a late night snack)
Other great places on campus (Flex/Dining Dollars/cash/credit card): Carleton Lounge (Mudd building), Cafe 212, Cafe East (both in Lerner)
Great places on and around campus that only take cash/credit card: Joe Coffee (Northwest Corner Building; you'll never go to Starbucks again), Brownie's Cafe (Avery), Nussbaum and Wu Cafe (113th and Broadway), Hungarian Pastry Shop (112th and Amsterdam)
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Could Be Better – The food in Columbia's 2 dining halls is okay, but it get's old after a while.  I greatly prefer Hewitt dining hall, which is right across the street at Barnard.  The food there is great, and there are always free seats, but many students complain that it's too far away (it's literally right across the street).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Go Find the Small Places Around Campus – Protip: get a meal plan with the smallest number of meals/most dining dollars. The cafeteria isn't bad by any rate, but even the best food will get boring if it becomes routine. So instead, use your dining dollars to eat at random sandwich shops and cafes around campus. If you're feeling super rich or adventurous, go off campus and experience the dining possiblities of NYC.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Good but Expensive – The dining around Columbia is diverse and delicious but will take a large bite out of your wallet.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Not Great – Columbia's dining halls aren't that great. Ferris always has the same things with the exception of a few things changing daily. I like to think of going to John Jay Dining hall as a gamble because you never know what to expect. I always play it safe and just get pasta at Ferris. On the weekend, it's best to just go out and explore the restaurants in the city.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Tons of Places for College Students – Although you're in NYC, you are in a part of the city that is dominated by Columbia University. Therefore, there are a TON of local restaurants with fairly cheap prices within ten blocks of campus-- and I mean a TON. And there isn't only quantity: there's also quality. The food is delicious and is from tons of different cultural backgrounds.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There Could Be Better in NYC – Factoring in that Columbia is in the city, relative to the rest of Manhattan, the food in Morningside is at best mediocre. Absolut Bagels is good as well as Artopolis, Mill Korean, and the Chipotle nearby, but in general, good food is all found downtown near NYU.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Satisfaction When Hungry – The places around campus are reasonable, if you're hungry and need to eat you will be satisfied!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Morningside Heights Is a "Culinary Wasteland" – While the city as a whole has tons of great dining options, Morningside Heights has few. There are a few options, ranging from dingy diner to upscale trendy restaurants. However, most options are too expensive for a college student's budget. That said, there are a few hidden gems. Saji's is a hole-in-the-wall Japanese place with great prices and consistently delicious food. Milano Market also has delicious (though pricy) sandwiches.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Food on Campus – The places around campus are good.Can't complain about dining hall food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Great Options, Tasty Food – There are many places to eat in the area, both on and off campus, and the University makes an effort to accommodate those with all types of dietary restrictions and allergies.  The food in the dining halls is tasty, and the restaurants in the area are fantastic. So much variety!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Morningside Heights – We've got a lot of good options right in Mo-Hi. For example, Artopolis has amazing crepes for under ten dollars, which if you split with a friend (they are enormous), is a pretty good deal. Crumbs recently opened if you need a cupcake fix, there's a Pinkberry, Chipotle, and 5 Guys if you crave fast-food and fro-yo. Head to Tom's for a delicious Broadway Shake and to Koronet's for a big slice of cheap pizza. There are numerous ethnic choices as well, try Massawa for a unique Ethiopian/Eritrean dining experience, as well as the Mill for tasty Korean options. Then again, there is always Westside Market with delicious and tasty salads and sandwiches. Prices are great if you know what to get and where to go.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Too Expensive for What It Is – you get a better value for better food at the many many many places around campus and in the city. No one is on the meal plan after freshman year.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining Halls – The food really is not that bad, but having a mandatory meal plan as a freshman makes it seem awful by the end of the year. I was very content with the dining halls for the first semester, but after not wanting to waste the 15 meals Columbia makes me have a week, I eat there way more than I would like to. Can't wait until next year when don't have a meal plan though!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
A Bite from the Big Apple – Take one step off campus, and you're surrounded by two things- restaurants and book shops! In terms of restaurants, there's a little bit of everything, but then, what did you expect? It's New York City!

Close to campus, there's Ollie's, a popular Chinese restaurant that's not completely wonderful- but, it makes up for the taste with the price. Very cheap! Also, we have Tom's Diner (the one from Seinfeld) if you like the touristy thing, and about a million little asian shops scattered around everywhere.

My favorite though is probably the Halal cart on 115th and Broadway. The guy who runs it is super nice, and you get a full dinner for $5! Also, Koronet's on 111th is the best pizza place in Morningside. The slices are (literally) bigger than my head!

Not to forget, we also have the requisite Starbuck's on every corner, although Oren's Daily Roast serves a much better coffee if you don't mind a few extra minutes of walking. 

Oh, and the Hungarian Pastry Shop on Amsterdam has free WiFi and AMAZING pastry! Bring your laptop and manage to snag a table, and you can make a cup of coffee and a Danish last through an entire 6 page paper!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Good Options – Columbia has a nice variety of food offerings, but everything does get old after a while. I do think, however, that a lot of students here complain more than necessary... everything's pretty good. Can't say much about the meat, but they have a lot of vegetarian/vegan options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Everything Within a Few Blocks of Campus – There're a lot of restaurants located around Columbia University. Go uptown or downtown to find amazing food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Sometimes Good, Sometimes Terrible – Whilst John Jay Dining Hall sometimes has nice things to offer, there's also days when it is rather bad. There is, however, always a nice variety of food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's in Manhattan - TONS OF OPTIONS – There are heaps of restaurants and food/beverage options around Columbia -whether you're looking for something foreign or just a pizza joint. There's also a ton of options at the supermarkets nearby and you can always grab the subway and head for Brooklyn or downtown Manhattan or elsewhere if you're looking for a different locale. Some of it is cheap, some not -just depends on how much you want to spend.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: John Jay Is Good for What It Is: a Dining Hall – With a variety of options, John Jay Dining Hall is adequate and a popular hangout amongst students. Despite really awkward hours and sketchy food from time to time, John Jay is very reliable. It is noted that students from other schools marvel at hos much better Columbia food is. A meal plan is a good idea. You do, however have NYC at your fingertips. Just keep in mind that it can get pricey.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: If You Can, Get Off the Plan – Food around Columbia is actually cheaper than at Columbia. $5 sandwiches abound, along with cheap Chinese food. Of course, it's not dirt cheap, this is New York, but the dining plan is $14 per meal, which is crazy
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Many Great Options Nearby – Amazing diversity of quality restaurants next to campus.  Not really cheap, but many options in the area.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Pretty Typical – While the food offered in the dining halls is pretty typical of normal college fare, culinary offerings in the surrounding areas are superb make them seem even more sub-par.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I did 1 year in freshmen housing in a single. I was very quiet and kept to myself. Small room, hallmates really gossipy. Typical ugly dorm furniture and that carpeting. You know the carpeting. I like living alone off-campus. Don't like being "watched" much or having to sign people into my home as an grown adult.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is expensive, but still much cheaper than renting a place off-campus. I loved living in Furnald even though it's known to be the "anti-social dorm". It's beautiful for one, and a very peaceful place to live.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing's not great, because like everything at Columbia, it's squeezed space-wise. Also, because of Columbia's hardcore-school-in-NY mien, there's not a great social atmosphere. But one usually makes do--I had a great first-year floor, for instance.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Most of the undergraduate housing is near campus. Students get to pick and choose, on the most part, where they desire to live. Each residential hall is different and has its own perks.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live off campus so I migth not be the best to rate all of this
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It's great to have housing in New York City available to you, but some buildings really need renovations. For the most part, I am incredibly happy with where I ended up and who I met as a result of that. Columbia housing is such an important part of the Columbia experience and it has such an impact on how you spend your time in college. I lived in Carman and because of that I was able to make great friends on my floor who helped me through my first year, through study groups and impromptu food runs. I wouldn't trade my time in Carman for the world.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's like having your own mini-apartment. A very personalized space.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing can be extremely hit-or-miss.  Some dorms are incredible. Others are mediocre.  And some are just awful.  It really is the luck of the draw (or housing lottery) that determines the quality of the housing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Being in New York, the rooms aren't huge.  But it's really easy for students to get singles as a first year, maintenance comes every week day to clean, and overall, it was great! I lived in John Jay and I absolutely loved it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Comparative to the housing on campus from the other schools I have lived at, it is a great experience.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It is better than finding your own place, but is far from glamorous.  Dealing with the housing department can be a hassle.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I love the specialty housing options.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing was easy to maneuver
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are fine but they're what you would expect in New York City -- cramped for property.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is good, but it's hard to get single in your sophomore year; moreover, singles are fairly small. However, overall experience is great.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in Carman and it's pretty spacious for a double. There's also a lot of closet space if that's what your looking for. There's a lot of parties in Carman
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in Hartley, which is known for being a sort of home-y dorm in that the dorm is suite style. Most suites seem to be alright but mine is pretty loud at the moment. It is a combination of sophomores and freshman but the sophomores tend to keep to themselves. I would have opted to be in Wallach or John Jay because I think the facilities are a bit better and the noise control is quieter. Carman is great for partying and Furnald is on the eclectic side.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
Columbia undergraduate housing is done in an lottery system in which each student is given a lottery number that determines when they can apply for their desired housing. The lottery system gives priority to seniors. Thus seniors get to choose their housing first, then juniors, and so on. The lottery system can be confusing, but Columbia Housing does a good job of clarifying it's process via email updates, website, flyers, and information sessions. All dorms have heaters while only some dorms have AC units in each room. It's best to live in corridor-style dorms with individual AC+heating unites in each room (such as Furnald, Broadway, John Jay, etc.) and these corridor-styles are more affordable than other dorms. Hartley is one of the worst dorms: (1) it's one of the oldest dorms so the carpet is old and dirty (bad for people with carpet, dust mite allergies); (2) no AC; (3) heater does not work in many rooms; (4) cockroach and mice infestation in lower floors if students share kitchen with untidy suite mates. 

Columbia resident halls have great security that ensure only valid undergraduate CU student ID holders can enter building unless guests are signed-in appropriately.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Freshman housing is the only housing that's 'on-campus,' between 120th and 114th between Broadway and Amsterdam (aside from the Living Learning Center). However, all of university-housing is within a few blocks of 'campus,' which is really great for cutting down on walking time to class. I haven't personally been through the housing selection process yet, but, I've heard that it's an absolute hassle.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Quality of housing depends on where you live on campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: No rodents or bugs! And our bathrooms are clean 80% of the time
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: NYC housing sucks and it always will.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Its very close to campus and decent rent.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I would suggest living in off-campus housing if you are looking for added freedom. Lots of student opt for off-campus housing instead of bothering with the bureaucratic school process.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Residing in the Upper West Side is an amazing experience because the local community is vibrant and very lively. The community is very diverse and the neighborhood is relatively safe despite preconceived notions that state otherwise. It also makes attending class very easy because Columbia's campus is quite far from the rest of the city so living on campus/near campus is the best option.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I've heard it can be great, but depends.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Rooms can be very small, many without A/C.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: New York is VERY expensive and as a graduate student the only option is off campus housing...
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Columbia University is wonderful in every way!  As a graduate student however, I have never lived ON campus myself, but from those who studied/are studying undergrad and have lived on campus they absolutely love it.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Freshman housing availability is pretty good, and there's a variety of options available. Best part is probably that housing is guaranteed for all four years of undergrad. Sophomore housing process can be a pain but can also go very smoothly. Overall, above average.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Unfortunately our lottery process is convoluted and annoying, making housing a very stressful ordeal in the middle of finals season. At the moment, I am a sophomore and sophomore housing tends to be the worst among the classes. Hopefully next year I get lucky.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living off campus all depends on what you're looking for, what you're willing to spend, and how far you're willing to travel. In general, it can be expensive, parking sucks but there is reliable public transit, and everything is a bit smaller if you live in the city. If you know someone who already lives around the area it be much easier to find someone who needs a roommate.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I can only speak for graduate housing, but it is a lottery system and your lucky if you get it. My friend last year was unable to get housing but was lucky to find people who needed a roommate one month before school started. Otherwise your stuck trying to find something around the area and city living can get expensive, especially if you're on your own. Just cross your fingers when you apply but look for a back-up in case.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Mix of older and newer buildings on the outside, new or plans on remodeling soon on the inside.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Columbia dorms are great. Easy waslk to everything. Small, intimate safe campus. There are also some high rises with great views.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: On campus housing is amazing. Everyone lives on campus.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: location is next to my school.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: It's great considering it's in Manhattan. Housing costs are pretty low considering how much an apartment would cost here.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I'm sure there's great off-campus housing if you're willing to pay for it. However, it's Manhattan, so obviously no one wants to pay an enormous sum of money when you could just stay on-campus. Something like 95% of students stay in Columbia housing all 4 years
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing in NYC is housing in NYC lol
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: New York housing is way too expensive.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: There are a lot of places to choose from if the lottery system doesn't screw you over, but it is expensive. Some dorms are more social than others.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: LOVED Carman hall freshman year!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is tiny, use the parks and outdoors as your own backyard.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Living in Columbia housing is a mixed bag. On the one hand, unless you have a trust fund, it is exceptional to live in guaranteed housing in NYC. It is conveniently close to all classroom buildings (for the most part) and is mostly clean. Freshman housing is nice and ideally located next to the main library and on top of the three dining halls. Sophomore year is a crap shoot, but it gets better, and getting singles all four years is not impossible. The housing lottery (after freshman year) is confusing, but any upperclassman can explain it, and people get a weird thrill out of calculating their probability of getting different rooms, so it ends up being a bonding experience. On the other hand, if you get stuck in a bad dorm, it really sucks. McBain and Nussbaum both have pest problems, and a lot of the dorms lack a/c, which sucks in September. But even then, you join a tradition of Columbia students who have dealt with the same problems for decades. As for a social scene in the dorms, it varies greatly depending on who you live with. I lived in the "anti-social" freshman dorm, Furnald, and had a great social life. So it is what you make of it.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Columbia does provide some cheap apartments off campus, but if you can't get one, apartments are very expensive and pretty hard to find in Manhattan.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Althoughthere arequite a number of aoartments around campus, they tend to just as expensiveor even slightly more exoensive the on-campus housing. Grad students normally opt for off-campus housing due to the added freedomand privacy.Undergradsoften go for on-campus housing because of the camaraderie of living with other freshmen and the fact that Columbia guarantees housing for all undergrads. I bet grad students would go for On-campus housingif it was guaranteed for them.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Same as last page. As well as it would be ideal to have refrigerators in the lounges. 99% of my money is going to eating out, because I can't store anything here.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Freshman residences are the best by far. Single rooms are pretty rare for sophomores, so as long as you make a friend or two you should be fine for the next year.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Not sure of the options available.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: No air condition. Could be a challenge when the weather is warm.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are kitchens in every suite and sometimes communal refrigerators (in specialty housing, they have everything from private dining halls to their own washing machines). Good value, constantly improved and updated.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If you share an apartment with more than three others then it can be affordable, and by that I mean roughly on-par with on-campus housing. Not much money is saved for the added inconvenience.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live off-campus so cannot comment on this topic.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing prices vary greatly.  If you are lucky you can find something nicer and cheaper than on campus housing.  However, you really have to be at the right place at the right time.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing is guaranteed for everyone which is cool. I have had a good housing experience. A variety of options that should satisfy everyone.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing in the neighborhood by medical campus is affordable yet the environment is not ideal.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Medical campus is located in a less than ideal neighborhood and facilities do not have aesthetic appeal.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Some of the residences are nice, some are decent, some are just awful. Though there have been initiatives to change this, there is currently no real "community" in Columbia dorms. Common areas are often empty and quiet hours are strictly enforced. Recently, students have been working to transform residence halls into smaller communities as opposed to just places students retreat to after all-nighters in the library.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing isn't the best but its good enough for living in New York City.
Housing.Author: College Freshman
